     394                 :            :         // This coin was checked in PreChecks and MemPoolAccept

     542                 :            :     /**

     597                 :            : 
     598                 :            :     // Run the policy checks on a given transaction, excluding any script checks.
     599                 :            :     // Looks up inputs, calculates feerate, considers replacement, evaluates
     600                 :            :     // package limits, etc. As this function can be invoked for "free" by a peer,
     601                 :            :     // only tests that are fast should be done here (to avoid CPU DoS).
     602                 :            :     bool PreChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     603                 :            : 
     604                 :            :     // Run checks for mempool replace-by-fee.
     605                 :            :     bool ReplacementChecks(Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     606                 :            : 
     607                 :            :     // Enforce package mempool ancestor/descendant limits (distinct from individual
     608                 :            :     // ancestor/descendant limits done in PreChecks).
     609                 :            :     bool PackageMempoolChecks(const std::vector<CTransactionRef>& txns,
     610                 :            :                               PackageValidationState& package_state) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     611                 :            : 
     612                 :            :     // Run the script checks using our policy flags. As this can be slow, we should
     613                 :            :     // only invoke this on transactions that have otherwise passed policy checks.
     614                 :            :     bool PolicyScriptChecks(const ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     615                 :            : 
     616                 :            :     // Re-run the script checks, using consensus flags, and try to cache the
     617                 :            :     // result in the scriptcache. This should be done after
     618                 :            :     // PolicyScriptChecks(). This requires that all inputs either be in our
     619                 :            :     // utxo set or in the mempool.

     622                 :            :     // Try to add the transaction to the mempool, removing any conflicts first.
     623                 :            :     // Returns true if the transaction is in the mempool after any size
     624                 :            :     // limiting is performed, false otherwise.

     626                 :            : 
     627                 :            :     // Submit all transactions to the mempool and call ConsensusScriptChecks to add to the script
     628                 :            :     // cache - should only be called after successful validation of all transactions in the package.

     722                 :            : 
     723                 :            :     // Check for conflicts with in-memory transactions
     724         [ +  + ]:     101127 :     for (const CTxIn &txin : tx.vin)
     725                 :            :     {
     726         [ +  - ]:      68327 :         const CTransaction* ptxConflicting = m_pool.GetConflictTx(txin.prevout);
     727         [ +  + ]:      68327 :         if (ptxConflicting) {
     728         [ +  + ]:       1181 :             if (!args.m_allow_replacement) {
     729                 :            :                 // Transaction conflicts with a mempool tx, but we're not allowing replacements.
     730   [ +  -  +  -  :          2 :                 return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "bip125-replacement-disallowed");
                   +  - ]
     731                 :            :             }
     732   [ +  -  +  + ]:       1180 :             if (!ws.m_conflicts.count(ptxConflicting->GetHash()))
     733                 :            :             {
     734                 :            :                 // Transactions that don't explicitly signal replaceability are
     735                 :            :                 // *not* replaceable with the current logic, even if one of their
     736                 :            :                 // unconfirmed ancestors signals replaceability. This diverges
     737                 :            :                 // from BIP125's inherited signaling description (see CVE-2021-31876).
     738                 :            :                 // Applications relying on first-seen mempool behavior should
     739                 :            :                 // check all unconfirmed ancestors; otherwise an opt-in ancestor
     740                 :            :                 // might be replaced, causing removal of this descendant.
     741                 :            :                 //
     742                 :            :                 // If replaceability signaling is ignored due to node setting,
     743                 :            :                 // replacement is always allowed.
     744   [ +  +  +  -  :       1168 :                 if (!m_pool.m_full_rbf && !SignalsOptInRBF(*ptxConflicting)) {
             +  +  +  + ]
     745   [ +  -  +  -  :         10 :                     return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "txn-mempool-conflict");
                   +  - ]
     746                 :            :                 }
     747                 :            : 
     748         [ +  - ]:       1163 :                 ws.m_conflicts.insert(ptxConflicting->GetHash());
     749                 :            :             }
     750                 :            :         }
     751                 :            :     }
     752                 :            : 
     753                 :      32800 :     LockPoints lp;
     754         [ +  - ]:      32800 :     m_view.SetBackend(m_viewmempool);

     842                 :            : 
     843         [ +  - ]:      28446 :     ws.m_iters_conflicting = m_pool.GetIterSet(ws.m_conflicts);
     844                 :            :     // Calculate in-mempool ancestors, up to a limit.
     845         [ +  + ]:      28446 :     if (ws.m_conflicts.size() == 1) {
     846                 :            :         // In general, when we receive an RBF transaction with mempool conflicts, we want to know whether we
     847                 :            :         // would meet the chain limits after the conflicts have been removed. However, there isn't a practical
     848                 :            :         // way to do this short of calculating the ancestor and descendant sets with an overlay cache of
     849                 :            :         // changed mempool entries. Due to both implementation and runtime complexity concerns, this isn't
     850                 :            :         // very realistic, thus we only ensure a limited set of transactions are RBF'able despite mempool
     851                 :            :         // conflicts here. Importantly, we need to ensure that some transactions which were accepted using
     852                 :            :         // the below carve-out are able to be RBF'ed, without impacting the security the carve-out provides
     853                 :            :         // for off-chain contract systems (see link in the comment below).
     854                 :            :         //
     855                 :            :         // Specifically, the subset of RBF transactions which we allow despite chain limits are those which
     856                 :            :         // conflict directly with exactly one other transaction (but may evict children of said transaction),
     857                 :            :         // and which are not adding any new mempool dependencies. Note that the "no new mempool dependencies"
     858                 :            :         // check is accomplished later, so we don't bother doing anything about it here, but if our
     859                 :            :         // policy changes, we may need to move that check to here instead of removing it wholesale.
     860                 :            :         //
     861                 :            :         // Such transactions are clearly not merging any existing packages, so we are only concerned with
     862                 :            :         // ensuring that (a) no package is growing past the package size (not count) limits and (b) we are
     863                 :            :         // not allowing something to effectively use the (below) carve-out spot when it shouldn't be allowed
     864                 :            :         // to.
     865                 :            :         //
     866                 :            :         // To check these we first check if we meet the RBF criteria, above, and increment the descendant
     867                 :            :         // limits by the direct conflict and its descendants (as these are recalculated in
     868                 :            :         // CalculateMempoolAncestors by assuming the new transaction being added is a new descendant, with no
     869                 :            :         // removals, of each parent's existing dependent set). The ancestor count limits are unmodified (as
     870                 :            :         // the ancestor limits should be the same for both our new transaction and any conflicts).
     871                 :            :         // We don't bother incrementing m_limit_descendants by the full removal count as that limit never comes
     872                 :            :         // into force here (as we're only adding a single transaction).
     873         [ -  + ]:        942 :         assert(ws.m_iters_conflicting.size() == 1);
     874                 :        942 :         CTxMemPool::txiter conflict = *ws.m_iters_conflicting.begin();
     875                 :            : 
     876                 :        942 :         m_limit_descendants += 1;
     877         [ +  - ]:        942 :         m_limit_descendant_size += conflict->GetSizeWithDescendants();
     878                 :            :     }
     879                 :            : 
     880                 :      56892 :     std::string errString;
     881   [ +  -  +  + ]:      28446 :     if (!m_pool.CalculateMemPoolAncestors(*entry, ws.m_ancestors, m_limit_ancestors, m_limit_ancestor_size, m_limit_descendants, m_limit_descendant_size, errString)) {
     882                 :        103 :         ws.m_ancestors.clear();
     883                 :            :         // If CalculateMemPoolAncestors fails second time, we want the original error string.
     884                 :        103 :         std::string dummy_err_string;
     885                 :            :         // Contracting/payment channels CPFP carve-out:
     886                 :            :         // If the new transaction is relatively small (up to 40k weight)
     887                 :            :         // and has at most one ancestor (ie ancestor limit of 2, including
     888                 :            :         // the new transaction), allow it if its parent has exactly the
     889                 :            :         // descendant limit descendants.
     890                 :            :         //
     891                 :            :         // This allows protocols which rely on distrusting counterparties
     892                 :            :         // being able to broadcast descendants of an unconfirmed transaction
     893                 :            :         // to be secure by simply only having two immediately-spendable
     894                 :            :         // outputs - one for each counterparty. For more info on the uses for
     895                 :            :         // this, see https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2018-November/016518.html

     916                 :        944 : bool MemPoolAccept::ReplacementChecks(Workspace& ws)
     917                 :            : {
     918                 :        944 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
     919                 :        944 :     AssertLockHeld(m_pool.cs);
     920                 :            : 
     921                 :        944 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
     922                 :        944 :     const uint256& hash = ws.m_hash;
     923                 :        944 :     TxValidationState& state = ws.m_state;
     924                 :            : 
     925                 :        944 :     CFeeRate newFeeRate(ws.m_modified_fees, ws.m_vsize);
     926                 :            :     // Enforce Rule #6. The replacement transaction must have a higher feerate than its direct conflicts.
     927                 :            :     // - The motivation for this check is to ensure that the replacement transaction is preferable for
     928                 :            :     //   block-inclusion, compared to what would be removed from the mempool.
     929                 :            :     // - This logic predates ancestor feerate-based transaction selection, which is why it doesn't
     930                 :            :     //   consider feerates of descendants.
     931                 :            :     // - Note: Ancestor feerate-based transaction selection has made this comparison insufficient to
     932                 :            :     //   guarantee that this is incentive-compatible for miners, because it is possible for a
     933                 :            :     //   descendant transaction of a direct conflict to pay a higher feerate than the transaction that
     934                 :            :     //   might replace them, under these rules.
     935         [ +  + ]:        944 :     if (const auto err_string{PaysMoreThanConflicts(ws.m_iters_conflicting, newFeeRate, hash)}) {

    1013                 :      25536 : bool MemPoolAccept::ConsensusScriptChecks(const ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws)
    1014                 :            : {
    1015                 :      25536 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1016                 :      25536 :     AssertLockHeld(m_pool.cs);
    1017                 :      25536 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
    1018                 :      25536 :     const uint256& hash = ws.m_hash;
    1019                 :      25536 :     TxValidationState& state = ws.m_state;
    1020                 :            : 
    1021                 :            :     // Check again against the current block tip's script verification
    1022                 :            :     // flags to cache our script execution flags. This is, of course,
    1023                 :            :     // useless if the next block has different script flags from the
    1024                 :            :     // previous one, but because the cache tracks script flags for us it
    1025                 :            :     // will auto-invalidate and we'll just have a few blocks of extra
    1026                 :            :     // misses on soft-fork activation.
    1027                 :            :     //
    1028                 :            :     // This is also useful in case of bugs in the standard flags that cause
    1029                 :            :     // transactions to pass as valid when they're actually invalid. For
    1030                 :            :     // instance the STRICTENC flag was incorrectly allowing certain
    1031                 :            :     // CHECKSIG NOT scripts to pass, even though they were invalid.
    1032                 :            :     //
    1033                 :            :     // There is a similar check in CreateNewBlock() to prevent creating
    1034                 :            :     // invalid blocks (using TestBlockValidity), however allowing such
    1035                 :            :     // transactions into the mempool can be exploited as a DoS attack.
    1036                 :      25536 :     unsigned int currentBlockScriptVerifyFlags{GetBlockScriptFlags(*m_active_chainstate.m_chain.Tip(), m_active_chainstate.m_chainman)};
    1037         [ -  + ]:      25536 :     if (!CheckInputsFromMempoolAndCache(tx, state, m_view, m_pool, currentBlockScriptVerifyFlags,

    1041                 :            :     }

    1046                 :      21664 : bool MemPoolAccept::Finalize(const ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws)
    1047                 :            : {

    1053                 :      21664 :     const bool bypass_limits = args.m_bypass_limits;
    1054                 :            : 
    1055                 :      21664 :     std::unique_ptr<CTxMemPoolEntry>& entry = ws.m_entry;
    1056                 :            : 
    1057                 :            :     // Remove conflicting transactions from the mempool
    1058         [ +  + ]:      22754 :     for (CTxMemPool::txiter it : ws.m_all_conflicting)
    1059                 :            :     {
    1060   [ +  -  +  -  :       3270 :         LogPrint(BCLog::MEMPOOL, "replacing tx %s with %s for %s additional fees, %d delta bytes\n",

    1278                 :         23 : PackageMempoolAcceptResult MemPoolAccept::AcceptPackage(const Package& package, ATMPArgs& args)
    1279                 :            : {
    1280                 :         23 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1281                 :         46 :     PackageValidationState package_state;
    1282                 :            : 
    1283                 :            :     // Check that the package is well-formed. If it isn't, we won't try to validate any of the
    1284                 :            :     // transactions and thus won't return any MempoolAcceptResults, just a package-wide error.
    1285                 :            : 
    1286                 :            :     // Context-free package checks.
    1287   [ +  -  -  +  :         23 :     if (!CheckPackage(package, package_state)) return PackageMempoolAcceptResult(package_state, {});
             -  -  -  - ]
    1288                 :            : 
    1289                 :            :     // All transactions in the package must be a parent of the last transaction. This is just an
    1290                 :            :     // opportunity for us to fail fast on a context-free check without taking the mempool lock.
    1291   [ +  -  +  + ]:         23 :     if (!IsChildWithParents(package)) {
    1292   [ +  -  +  -  :          6 :         package_state.Invalid(PackageValidationResult::PCKG_POLICY, "package-not-child-with-parents");

    1294                 :            :     }
    1295                 :            : 
    1296                 :            :     // IsChildWithParents() guarantees the package is > 1 transactions.
    1297         [ -  + ]:         20 :     assert(package.size() > 1);

    1299                 :            :     // be sorted, so the last transaction is the child.
    1300                 :         20 :     const auto& child = package.back();

    1302                 :         20 :     std::transform(package.cbegin(), package.cend() - 1,
    1303                 :            :                    std::inserter(unconfirmed_parent_txids, unconfirmed_parent_txids.end()),
    1304   [ +  -  +  - ]:        111 :                    [](const auto& tx) { return tx->GetHash(); });
    1305                 :            : 
    1306                 :            :     // All child inputs must refer to a preceding package transaction or a confirmed UTXO. The only
    1307                 :            :     // way to verify this is to look up the child's inputs in our current coins view (not including
    1308                 :            :     // mempool), and enforce that all parents not present in the package be available at chain tip.
    1309                 :            :     // Since this check can bring new coins into the coins cache, keep track of these coins and
    1310                 :            :     // uncache them if we don't end up submitting this package to the mempool.
    1311         [ +  - ]:         20 :     const CCoinsViewCache& coins_tip_cache = m_active_chainstate.CoinsTip();

    1315                 :            :         }
    1316                 :            :     }
    1317                 :            :     // Using the MemPoolAccept m_view cache allows us to look up these same coins faster later.
    1318                 :            :     // This should be connecting directly to CoinsTip, not to m_viewmempool, because we specifically
    1319                 :            :     // require inputs to be confirmed if they aren't in the package.

    1323                 :         20 :     };
    1324   [ +  -  +  + ]:         20 :     if (!std::all_of(child->vin.cbegin(), child->vin.cend(), package_or_confirmed)) {
    1325   [ +  -  +  -  :          2 :         package_state.Invalid(PackageValidationResult::PCKG_POLICY, "package-not-child-with-unconfirmed-parents");
                   +  - ]
    1326   [ +  -  +  - ]:          1 :         return PackageMempoolAcceptResult(package_state, {});
    1327                 :            :     }
    1328                 :            :     // Protect against bugs where we pull more inputs from disk that miss being added to
    1329                 :            :     // coins_to_uncache. The backend will be connected again when needed in PreChecks.
    1330         [ +  - ]:         19 :     m_view.SetBackend(m_dummy);
    1331                 :            : 
    1332         [ +  - ]:         38 :     LOCK(m_pool.cs);
    1333                 :         38 :     std::map<const uint256, const MempoolAcceptResult> results;
    1334                 :            :     // Node operators are free to set their mempool policies however they please, nodes may receive
    1335                 :            :     // transactions in different orders, and malicious counterparties may try to take advantage of
    1336                 :            :     // policy differences to pin or delay propagation of transactions. As such, it's possible for
    1337                 :            :     // some package transaction(s) to already be in the mempool, and we don't want to reject the
    1338                 :            :     // entire package in that case (as that could be a censorship vector). De-duplicate the
    1339                 :            :     // transactions that are already in the mempool, and only call AcceptMultipleTransactions() with
    1340                 :            :     // the new transactions. This ensures we don't double-count transaction counts and sizes when
    1341                 :            :     // checking ancestor/descendant limits, or double-count transaction fees for fee-related policy.
    1342         [ +  - ]:         19 :     ATMPArgs single_args = ATMPArgs::SingleInPackageAccept(args);
    1343                 :         19 :     bool quit_early{false};
    1344                 :         38 :     std::vector<CTransactionRef> txns_new;
    1345         [ +  + ]:        108 :     for (const auto& tx : package) {
    1346                 :         89 :         const auto& wtxid = tx->GetWitnessHash();
    1347                 :         89 :         const auto& txid = tx->GetHash();
    1348                 :            :         // There are 3 possibilities: already in mempool, same-txid-diff-wtxid already in mempool,
    1349                 :            :         // or not in mempool. An already confirmed tx is treated as one not in mempool, because all
    1350                 :            :         // we know is that the inputs aren't available.
    1351   [ +  -  +  + ]:         89 :         if (m_pool.exists(GenTxid::Wtxid(wtxid))) {
    1352                 :            :             // Exact transaction already exists in the mempool.
    1353         [ +  - ]:         17 :             auto iter = m_pool.GetIter(txid);
    1354         [ -  + ]:         17 :             assert(iter != std::nullopt);
    1355   [ +  -  +  -  :         17 :             results.emplace(wtxid, MempoolAcceptResult::MempoolTx(iter.value()->GetTxSize(), iter.value()->GetFee()));
          +  -  +  -  +  
             -  +  -  +  
                      - ]
    1356   [ +  -  +  + ]:         72 :         } else if (m_pool.exists(GenTxid::Txid(txid))) {
    1357                 :            :             // Transaction with the same non-witness data but different witness (same txid,
    1358                 :            :             // different wtxid) already exists in the mempool.
    1359                 :            :             //
    1360                 :            :             // We don't allow replacement transactions right now, so just swap the package
    1361                 :            :             // transaction for the mempool one. Note that we are ignoring the validity of the
    1362                 :            :             // package transaction passed in.
    1363                 :            :             // TODO: allow witness replacement in packages.
    1364         [ +  - ]:          3 :             auto iter = m_pool.GetIter(txid);

    1367   [ +  -  +  -  :          3 :             results.emplace(wtxid, MempoolAcceptResult::MempoolTxDifferentWitness(iter.value()->GetTx().GetWitnessHash()));

    1369                 :            :             // Transaction does not already exist in the mempool.
    1370                 :            :             // Try submitting the transaction on its own.

    1372         [ +  + ]:         69 :             if (single_res.m_result_type == MempoolAcceptResult::ResultType::VALID) {

    1377   [ +  +  -  +  :         19 :             } else if (single_res.m_state.GetResult() != TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY &&
                   -  + ]
    1378                 :          6 :                        single_res.m_state.GetResult() != TxValidationResult::TX_MISSING_INPUTS) {
    1379                 :            :                 // Package validation policy only differs from individual policy in its evaluation
    1380                 :            :                 // of feerate. For example, if a transaction fails here due to violation of a
    1381                 :            :                 // consensus rule, the result will not change when it is submitted as part of a
    1382                 :            :                 // package. To minimize the amount of repeated work, unless the transaction fails
    1383                 :            :                 // due to feerate or missing inputs (its parent is a previous transaction in the
    1384                 :            :                 // package that failed due to feerate), don't run package validation. Note that this
    1385                 :            :                 // decision might not make sense if different types of packages are allowed in the
    1386                 :            :                 // future.  Continue individually validating the rest of the transactions, because
    1387                 :            :                 // some of them may still be valid.

    1636                 :       1353 : bool InitScriptExecutionCache(size_t max_size_bytes)
    1637                 :            : {
    1638                 :            :     // Setup the salted hasher
    1639                 :       1353 :     uint256 nonce = GetRandHash();
    1640                 :            :     // We want the nonce to be 64 bytes long to force the hasher to process
    1641                 :            :     // this chunk, which makes later hash computations more efficient. We
    1642                 :            :     // just write our 32-byte entropy twice to fill the 64 bytes.
    1643                 :       1353 :     g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher.Write(nonce.begin(), 32);
    1644                 :       1353 :     g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher.Write(nonce.begin(), 32);
    1645                 :            :

    1647         [ -  + ]:       1353 :     if (!setup_results) return false;

    1652                 :       1353 :     return true;
    1653                 :            : }
    1654                 :            : 
    1655                 :            : /**
    1656                 :            :  * Check whether all of this transaction's input scripts succeed.
    1657                 :            :  *
    1658                 :            :  * This involves ECDSA signature checks so can be computationally intensive. This function should
    1659                 :            :  * only be called after the cheap sanity checks in CheckTxInputs passed.
    1660                 :            :  *
    1661                 :            :  * If pvChecks is not nullptr, script checks are pushed onto it instead of being performed inline. Any
    1662                 :            :  * script checks which are not necessary (eg due to script execution cache hits) are, obviously,
    1663                 :            :  * not pushed onto pvChecks/run.
    1664                 :            :  *
    1665                 :            :  * Setting cacheSigStore/cacheFullScriptStore to false will remove elements from the corresponding cache
    1666                 :            :  * which are matched. This is useful for checking blocks where we will likely never need the cache
    1667                 :            :  * entry again.
    1668                 :            :  *
    1669                 :            :  * Note that we may set state.reason to NOT_STANDARD for extra soft-fork flags in flags, block-checking
    1670                 :            :  * callers should probably reset it to CONSENSUS in such cases.
    1671                 :            :  *
    1672                 :            :  * Non-static (and re-declared) in src/test/txvalidationcache_tests.cpp
    1673                 :            :  */
    1674                 :     253450 : bool CheckInputScripts(const CTransaction& tx, TxValidationState& state,
    1675                 :            :                        const CCoinsViewCache& inputs, unsigned int flags, bool cacheSigStore,
    1676                 :            :                        bool cacheFullScriptStore, PrecomputedTransactionData& txdata,
    1677                 :            :                        std::vector<CScriptCheck>* pvChecks)
    1678                 :            : {
    1679         [ -  + ]:     253450 :     if (tx.IsCoinBase()) return true;
    1680                 :            : 
    1681         [ +  + ]:     253450 :     if (pvChecks) {
    1682                 :     124415 :         pvChecks->reserve(tx.vin.size());
    1683                 :            :     }
    1684                 :            : 
    1685                 :            :     // First check if script executions have been cached with the same
    1686                 :            :     // flags. Note that this assumes that the inputs provided are
    1687                 :            :     // correct (ie that the transaction hash which is in tx's prevouts
    1688                 :            :     // properly commits to the scriptPubKey in the inputs view of that
    1689                 :            :     // transaction).
    1690                 :     253450 :     uint256 hashCacheEntry;
    1691                 :     253450 :     CSHA256 hasher = g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher;
    1692                 :     253450 :     hasher.Write(tx.GetWitnessHash().begin(), 32).Write((unsigned char*)&flags, sizeof(flags)).Finalize(hashCacheEntry.begin());

    1694         [ +  + ]:     253450 :     if (g_scriptExecutionCache.contains(hashCacheEntry, !cacheFullScriptStore)) {
    1695                 :      65389 :         return true;
    1696                 :            :     }
    1697                 :            : 
    1698         [ +  + ]:     188061 :     if (!txdata.m_spent_outputs_ready) {
    1699                 :     120616 :         std::vector<CTxOut> spent_outputs;
    1700         [ +  - ]:      60308 :         spent_outputs.reserve(tx.vin.size());
    1701                 :            : 
    1702         [ +  + ]:     170404 :         for (const auto& txin : tx.vin) {
    1703                 :     110096 :             const COutPoint& prevout = txin.prevout;
    1704         [ +  - ]:     110096 :             const Coin& coin = inputs.AccessCoin(prevout);

    1881                 :            :     // retroactively applied to testnet)

    1927                 :            : static bool ContextualBlockPreCheck(const CBlock& block, BlockValidationState& state, const ChainstateManager& chainman, const CBlockIndex* pindexPrev);

    1938                 :            : /** Apply the effects of this block (with given index) on the UTXO set represented by coins.
    1939                 :            :  *  Validity checks that depend on the UTXO set are also done; ConnectBlock()
    1940                 :            :  *  can fail if those validity checks fail (among other reasons). */
    1941                 :     122616 : bool Chainstate::ConnectBlock(const CBlock& block, BlockValidationState& state, CBlockIndex* pindex,
    1942                 :            :                                CCoinsViewCache& view, bool fJustCheck)
    1943                 :            : {
    1944                 :     122616 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);

    1946                 :            : 
    1947                 :     122616 :     uint256 block_hash{block.GetHash()};

    1949                 :            : 
    1950                 :     122616 :     int64_t nTimeStart = GetTimeMicros();
    1951                 :            : 
    1952         [ -  + ]:     122616 :     if (!ContextualBlockPreCheck(block, state, m_chainman, pindex->pprev)) {
    1953         [ #  # ]:          0 :         return error("%s: Consensus::ContextualBlockPreCheck: %s", __func__, state.ToString());
    1954                 :            :     }
    1955                 :            : 
    1956                 :            :     // Check it again in case a previous version let a bad block in
    1957                 :            :     // NOTE: We don't currently (re-)invoke ContextualCheckBlock() or
    1958                 :            :     // ContextualCheckBlockHeader() here. This means that if we add a new
    1959                 :            :     // consensus rule that is enforced in one of those two functions, then we
    1960                 :            :     // may have let in a block that violates the rule prior to updating the
    1961                 :            :     // software, and we would NOT be enforcing the rule here. Fully solving
    1962                 :            :     // upgrade from one software version to the next after a consensus rule
    1963                 :            :     // change is potentially tricky and issue-specific (see NeedsRedownload()
    1964                 :            :     // for one approach that was used for BIP 141 deployment).
    1965                 :            :     // Also, currently the rule against blocks more than 2 hours in the future
    1966                 :            :     // is enforced in ContextualCheckBlockHeader(); we wouldn't want to
    1967                 :            :     // re-enforce that rule here (at least until we make it impossible for
    1968                 :            :     // m_adjusted_time_callback() to go backward).
    1969         [ -  + ]:     122616 :     if (!CheckBlock(block, state, m_params.GetConsensus(), !fJustCheck, !fJustCheck)) {
    1970         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (state.GetResult() == BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED) {
    1971                 :            :             // We don't write down blocks to disk if they may have been
    1972                 :            :             // corrupted, so this should be impossible unless we're having hardware
    1973                 :            :             // problems.
    1974   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             return AbortNode(state, "Corrupt block found indicating potential hardware failure; shutting down");
    1975                 :            :         }
    1976         [ #  # ]:          0 :         return error("%s: Consensus::CheckBlock: %s", __func__, state.ToString());

    1978                 :            : 
    1979                 :            :     // verify that the view's current state corresponds to the previous block
    1980         [ +  + ]:     122616 :     uint256 hashPrevBlock = pindex->pprev == nullptr ? uint256() : pindex->pprev->GetBlockHash();
    1981         [ -  + ]:     122616 :     assert(hashPrevBlock == view.GetBestBlock());
    1982                 :            : 
    1983                 :     122616 :     nBlocksTotal++;
    1984                 :            : 
    1985                 :            :     // Special case for the genesis block, skipping connection of its transactions
    1986                 :            :     // (its coinbase is unspendable)

    1989                 :        407 :             view.SetBestBlock(pindex->GetBlockHash());
    1990                 :        407 :         return true;
    1991                 :            :     }
    1992                 :            : 
    1993                 :     122209 :     bool fScriptChecks = true;
    1994         [ +  + ]:     122209 :     if (!hashAssumeValid.IsNull()) {
    1995                 :            :         // We've been configured with the hash of a block which has been externally verified to have a valid history.
    1996                 :            :         // A suitable default value is included with the software and updated from time to time.  Because validity
    1997                 :            :         //  relative to a piece of software is an objective fact these defaults can be easily reviewed.
    1998                 :            :         // This setting doesn't force the selection of any particular chain but makes validating some faster by
    1999                 :            :         //  effectively caching the result of part of the verification.
    2000                 :       2442 :         BlockMap::const_iterator  it = m_blockman.m_block_index.find(hashAssumeValid);
    2001         [ +  + ]:       2442 :         if (it != m_blockman.m_block_index.end()) {
    2002                 :       2304 :             if (it->second.GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    2003   [ +  +  +  -  :       2508 :                 m_chainman.m_best_header->GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
                   +  + ]
    2004         [ +  - ]:        204 :                 m_chainman.m_best_header->nChainWork >= nMinimumChainWork) {
    2005                 :            :                 // This block is a member of the assumed verified chain and an ancestor of the best header.
    2006                 :            :                 // Script verification is skipped when connecting blocks under the
    2007                 :            :                 // assumevalid block. Assuming the assumevalid block is valid this
    2008                 :            :                 // is safe because block merkle hashes are still computed and checked,
    2009                 :            :                 // Of course, if an assumed valid block is invalid due to false scriptSigs
    2010                 :            :                 // this optimization would allow an invalid chain to be accepted.
    2011                 :            :                 // The equivalent time check discourages hash power from extorting the network via DOS attack
    2012                 :            :                 //  into accepting an invalid block through telling users they must manually set assumevalid.
    2013                 :            :                 //  Requiring a software change or burying the invalid block, regardless of the setting, makes
    2014                 :            :                 //  it hard to hide the implication of the demand.  This also avoids having release candidates
    2015                 :            :                 //  that are hardly doing any signature verification at all in testing without having to
    2016                 :            :                 //  artificially set the default assumed verified block further back.
    2017                 :            :                 // The test against nMinimumChainWork prevents the skipping when denied access to any chain at
    2018                 :            :                 //  least as good as the expected chain.
    2019                 :        204 :                 fScriptChecks = (GetBlockProofEquivalentTime(*m_chainman.m_best_header, *pindex, *m_chainman.m_best_header, m_params.GetConsensus()) <= 60 * 60 * 24 * 7 * 2);
    2020                 :            :             }
    2021                 :            :         }
    2022                 :            :     }
    2023                 :            : 
    2024                 :     122209 :     int64_t nTime1 = GetTimeMicros(); nTimeCheck += nTime1 - nTimeStart;
    2025   [ +  -  +  -  :     244418 :     LogPrint(BCLog::BENCH, "    - Sanity checks: %.2fms [%.2fs (%.2fms/blk)]\n", MILLI * (nTime1 - nTimeStart), nTimeCheck * MICRO, nTimeCheck * MILLI / nBlocksTotal);
             +  -  +  - ]
    2026                 :            : 
    2027                 :            :     // Do not allow blocks that contain transactions which 'overwrite' older transactions,
    2028                 :            :     // unless those are already completely spent.
    2029                 :            :     // If such overwrites are allowed, coinbases and transactions depending upon those
    2030                 :            :     // can be duplicated to remove the ability to spend the first instance -- even after
    2031                 :            :     // being sent to another address.
    2032                 :            :     // See BIP30, CVE-2012-1909, and http://r6.ca/blog/20120206T005236Z.html for more information.
    2033                 :            :     // This rule was originally applied to all blocks with a timestamp after March 15, 2012, 0:00 UTC.
    2034                 :            :     // Now that the whole chain is irreversibly beyond that time it is applied to all blocks except the
    2035                 :            :     // two in the chain that violate it. This prevents exploiting the issue against nodes during their
    2036                 :            :     // initial block download.
    2037   [ -  +  -  - ]:     244418 :     bool fEnforceBIP30 = !((pindex->nHeight==91842 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256S("0x00000000000a4d0a398161ffc163c503763b1f4360639393e0e4c8e300e0caec")) ||
    2038   [ -  +  -  - ]:     122209 :                            (pindex->nHeight==91880 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256S("0x00000000000743f190a18c5577a3c2d2a1f610ae9601ac046a38084ccb7cd721")));
    2039                 :            : 
    2040                 :            :     // Once BIP34 activated it was not possible to create new duplicate coinbases and thus other than starting
    2041                 :            :     // with the 2 existing duplicate coinbase pairs, not possible to create overwriting txs.  But by the
    2042                 :            :     // time BIP34 activated, in each of the existing pairs the duplicate coinbase had overwritten the first
    2043                 :            :     // before the first had been spent.  Since those coinbases are sufficiently buried it's no longer possible to create further
    2044                 :            :     // duplicate transactions descending from the known pairs either.
    2045                 :            :     // If we're on the known chain at height greater than where BIP34 activated, we can save the db accesses needed for the BIP30 check.
    2046                 :            : 
    2047                 :            :     // BIP34 requires that a block at height X (block X) has its coinbase
    2048                 :            :     // scriptSig start with a CScriptNum of X (indicated height X).  The above
    2049                 :            :     // logic of no longer requiring BIP30 once BIP34 activates is flawed in the
    2050                 :            :     // case that there is a block X before the BIP34 height of 227,931 which has
    2051                 :            :     // an indicated height Y where Y is greater than X.  The coinbase for block
    2052                 :            :     // X would also be a valid coinbase for block Y, which could be a BIP30
    2053                 :            :     // violation.  An exhaustive search of all mainnet coinbases before the
    2054                 :            :     // BIP34 height which have an indicated height greater than the block height
    2055                 :            :     // reveals many occurrences. The 3 lowest indicated heights found are
    2056                 :            :     // 209,921, 490,897, and 1,983,702 and thus coinbases for blocks at these 3
    2057                 :            :     // heights would be the first opportunity for BIP30 to be violated.
    2058                 :            : 
    2059                 :            :     // The search reveals a great many blocks which have an indicated height
    2060                 :            :     // greater than 1,983,702, so we simply remove the optimization to skip
    2061                 :            :     // BIP30 checking for blocks at height 1,983,702 or higher.  Before we reach
    2062                 :            :     // that block in another 25 years or so, we should take advantage of a
    2063                 :            :     // future consensus change to do a new and improved version of BIP34 that
    2064                 :            :     // will actually prevent ever creating any duplicate coinbases in the
    2065                 :            :     // future.
    2066                 :            :     static constexpr int BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT = 1983702;
    2067                 :            : 
    2068                 :            :     // There is no potential to create a duplicate coinbase at block 209,921
    2069                 :            :     // because this is still before the BIP34 height and so explicit BIP30
    2070                 :            :     // checking is still active.
    2071                 :            : 
    2072                 :            :     // The final case is block 176,684 which has an indicated height of
    2073                 :            :     // 490,897. Unfortunately, this issue was not discovered until about 2 weeks
    2074                 :            :     // before block 490,897 so there was not much opportunity to address this
    2075                 :            :     // case other than to carefully analyze it and determine it would not be a
    2076                 :            :     // problem. Block 490,897 was, in fact, mined with a different coinbase than
    2077                 :            :     // block 176,684, but it is important to note that even if it hadn't been or
    2078                 :            :     // is remined on an alternate fork with a duplicate coinbase, we would still
    2079                 :            :     // not run into a BIP30 violation.  This is because the coinbase for 176,684
    2080                 :            :     // is spent in block 185,956 in transaction
    2081                 :            :     // d4f7fbbf92f4a3014a230b2dc70b8058d02eb36ac06b4a0736d9d60eaa9e8781.  This
    2082                 :            :     // spending transaction can't be duplicated because it also spends coinbase
    2083                 :            :     // 0328dd85c331237f18e781d692c92de57649529bd5edf1d01036daea32ffde29.  This
    2084                 :            :     // coinbase has an indicated height of over 4.2 billion, and wouldn't be
    2085                 :            :     // duplicatable until that height, and it's currently impossible to create a
    2086                 :            :     // chain that long. Nevertheless we may wish to consider a future soft fork
    2087                 :            :     // which retroactively prevents block 490,897 from creating a duplicate
    2088                 :            :     // coinbase. The two historical BIP30 violations often provide a confusing
    2089                 :            :     // edge case when manipulating the UTXO and it would be simpler not to have
    2090                 :            :     // another edge case to deal with.
    2091                 :            : 
    2092                 :            :     // testnet3 has no blocks before the BIP34 height with indicated heights
    2093                 :            :     // post BIP34 before approximately height 486,000,000. After block
    2094                 :            :     // 1,983,702 testnet3 starts doing unnecessary BIP30 checking again.
    2095         [ -  + ]:     122209 :     assert(pindex->pprev);
    2096                 :     122209 :     CBlockIndex* pindexBIP34height = pindex->pprev->GetAncestor(m_params.GetConsensus().BIP34Height);
    2097                 :            :     //Only continue to enforce if we're below BIP34 activation height or the block hash at that height doesn't correspond.
    2098   [ +  -  +  +  :     122209 :     fEnforceBIP30 = fEnforceBIP30 && (!pindexBIP34height || !(pindexBIP34height->GetBlockHash() == m_params.GetConsensus().BIP34Hash));
                   +  - ]
    2099                 :            : 
    2100                 :            :     // TODO: Remove BIP30 checking from block height 1,983,702 on, once we have a
    2101                 :            :     // consensus change that ensures coinbases at those heights cannot
    2102                 :            :     // duplicate earlier coinbases.
    2103   [ -  +  -  - ]:     122209 :     if (fEnforceBIP30 || pindex->nHeight >= BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT) {
    2104         [ +  + ]:     304033 :         for (const auto& tx : block.vtx) {
    2105         [ +  + ]:     701920 :             for (size_t o = 0; o < tx->vout.size(); o++) {
    2106         [ +  + ]:     520096 :                 if (view.HaveCoin(COutPoint(tx->GetHash(), o))) {
    2107   [ +  -  +  -  :          2 :                     LogPrintf("ERROR: ConnectBlock(): tried to overwrite transaction\n");
                   +  - ]
    2108   [ +  -  +  -  :          2 :                     return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_CONSENSUS, "bad-txns-BIP30");
                   +  - ]
    2109                 :            :                 }
    2110                 :            :             }
    2111                 :            :         }
    2112                 :            :     }

    2115                 :     122208 :     int nLockTimeFlags = 0;

             +  -  +  - ]
    2125                 :            :

    2127                 :            :

    2129                 :            :     // until after `control` has run the script checks (potentially
    2130                 :            :     // in multiple threads). Preallocate the vector size so a new allocation
    2131                 :            :     // doesn't invalidate pointers into the vector, and keep txsdata in scope

    2146                 :            :

    2501                 :            : /** Disconnect m_chain's tip.

    2503                 :            :   * transactions from disconnected blocks being added to disconnectpool.  You

    2609                 :      79458 :     std::vector<PerBlockConnectTrace>& GetBlocksConnected() {
    2610                 :            :         // We always keep one extra block at the end of our list because
    2611                 :            :         // blocks are added after all the conflicted transactions have
    2612                 :            :         // been filled in. Thus, the last entry should always be an empty
    2613                 :            :         // one waiting for the transactions from the next block. We pop
    2614                 :            :         // the last entry here to make sure the list we return is sane.

    2904                 :            :     // because this function periodically releases cs_main so that it does not lock up other threads for too long
    2905                 :            :     // during large connects - and to allow for e.g. the callback queue to drain

    3436                 :            : /**

    3484                 :            :     }
    3485                 :            : 
    3486                 :            :     // Enforce rule that the coinbase starts with serialized block height
    3487         [ +  + ]:     120661 :     if (DeploymentActiveAfter(pindexPrev, chainman, Consensus::DEPLOYMENT_HEIGHTINCB))

    3489   [ +  -  +  - ]:     120522 :         CScript expect = CScript() << nHeight;

                   +  - ]
    3493                 :            :         }
    3494                 :            :     }
    3495                 :            : 
    3496                 :            :     // Validation for witness commitments.
    3497                 :            :     // * We compute the witness hash (which is the hash including witnesses) of all the block's transactions, except the
    3498                 :            :     //   coinbase (where 0x0000....0000 is used instead).
    3499                 :            :     // * The coinbase scriptWitness is a stack of a single 32-byte vector, containing a witness reserved value (unconstrained).
    3500                 :            :     // * We build a merkle tree with all those witness hashes as leaves (similar to the hashMerkleRoot in the block header).
    3501                 :            :     // * There must be at least one output whose scriptPubKey is a single 36-byte push, the first 4 bytes of which are
    3502                 :            :     //   {0xaa, 0x21, 0xa9, 0xed}, and the following 32 bytes are SHA256^2(witness root, witness reserved value). In case there are
    3503                 :            :     //   multiple, the last one is used.
    3504                 :     120660 :     bool fHaveWitness = false;
    3505         [ +  + ]:     120660 :     if (DeploymentActiveAfter(pindexPrev, chainman, Consensus::DEPLOYMENT_SEGWIT)) {
    3506                 :     118631 :         int commitpos = GetWitnessCommitmentIndex(block);
    3507         [ +  + ]:     118631 :         if (commitpos != NO_WITNESS_COMMITMENT) {
    3508                 :     112403 :             bool malleated = false;
    3509                 :     112403 :             uint256 hashWitness = BlockWitnessMerkleRoot(block, &malleated);
    3510                 :            :             // The malleation check is ignored; as the transaction tree itself
    3511                 :            :             // already does not permit it, it is impossible to trigger in the
    3512                 :            :             // witness tree.
    3513   [ +  +  -  +  :     112403 :             if (block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack.size() != 1 || block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack[0].size() != 32) {

    3514   [ +  -  +  - ]:         12 :                 return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED, "bad-witness-nonce-size", strprintf("%s : invalid witness reserved value size", __func__));
    3515                 :            :             }
    3516                 :     112397 :             CHash256().Write(hashWitness).Write(block.vtx[0]->vin[0].scriptWitness.stack[0]).Finalize(hashWitness);
    3517         [ +  + ]:     112397 :             if (memcmp(hashWitness.begin(), &block.vtx[0]->vout[commitpos].scriptPubKey[6], 32)) {
    3518   [ +  -  +  - ]:          6 :                 return state.Invalid(BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED, "bad-witness-merkle-match", strprintf("%s : witness merkle commitment mismatch", __func__));
    3519                 :            :             }
    3520                 :     112394 :             fHaveWitness = true;
    3521                 :            :         }
    3522                 :            :     }
    3523                 :            : 
    3524                 :            :     // No witness data is allowed in blocks that don't commit to witness data, as this would otherwise leave room for spam

    3530                 :            :         }
    3531                 :            :     }
    3532                 :            : 
    3533                 :            :     // After the coinbase witness reserved value and commitment are verified,
    3534                 :            :     // we can check if the block weight passes (before we've checked the
    3535                 :            :     // coinbase witness, it would be possible for the weight to be too
    3536                 :            :     // large by filling up the coinbase witness, which doesn't change
    3537                 :            :     // the block hash, so we couldn't mark the block as permanently

    3587                 :            : 
    3588                 :            :         /* Determine if this block descends from any block which has been found
    3589                 :            :          * invalid (m_failed_blocks), then mark pindexPrev and any blocks between
    3590                 :            :          * them as failed. For example:
    3591                 :            :          *
    3592                 :            :          *                D3
    3593                 :            :          *              /
    3594                 :            :          *      B2 - C2
    3595                 :            :          *    /         \
    3596                 :            :          *  A             D2 - E2 - F2
    3597                 :            :          *    \
    3598                 :            :          *      B1 - C1 - D1 - E1
    3599                 :            :          *
    3600                 :            :          * In the case that we attempted to reorg from E1 to F2, only to find
    3601                 :            :          * C2 to be invalid, we would mark D2, E2, and F2 as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD
    3602                 :            :          * but NOT D3 (it was not in any of our candidate sets at the time).
    3603                 :            :          *
    3604                 :            :          * In any case D3 will also be marked as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD at restart
    3605                 :            :          * in LoadBlockIndex.
    3606                 :            :          */
    3607         [ +  + ]:      99491 :         if (!pindexPrev->IsValid(BLOCK_VALID_SCRIPTS)) {
    3608                 :            :             // The above does not mean "invalid": it checks if the previous block
    3609                 :            :             // hasn't been validated up to BLOCK_VALID_SCRIPTS. This is a performance
    3610                 :            :             // optimization, in the common case of adding a new block to the tip,
    3611                 :            :             // we don't need to iterate over the failed blocks list.
    3612         [ +  + ]:     100512 :             for (const CBlockIndex* failedit : m_failed_blocks) {

    3639                 :            : // Exposed wrapper for AcceptBlockHeader

    4194         [ -  - ]:      74960 :                      (pindex->HaveTxsDownloaded() || pindex->pprev == nullptr))) {
    4195                 :            : 
    4196                 :            :                 // Fill each chainstate's block candidate set. Only add assumed-valid
    4197                 :            :                 // blocks to the tip candidate set if the chainstate is allowed to rely on
    4198                 :            :                 // assumed-valid blocks.
    4199                 :            :                 //
    4200                 :            :                 // If all setBlockIndexCandidates contained the assumed-valid blocks, the
    4201                 :            :                 // background chainstate's ActivateBestChain() call would add assumed-valid
    4202                 :            :                 // blocks to the chain (based on how FindMostWorkChain() works). Obviously
    4203                 :            :                 // we don't want this since the purpose of the background validation chain
    4204                 :            :                 // is to validate assued-valid blocks.
    4205                 :            :                 //
    4206                 :            :                 // Note: This is considering all blocks whose height is greater or equal to
    4207                 :            :                 // the first assumed-valid block to be assumed-valid blocks, and excluding
    4208                 :            :                 // them from the background chainstate's setBlockIndexCandidates set. This
    4209                 :            :                 // does mean that some blocks which are not technically assumed-valid
    4210                 :            :                 // (later blocks on a fork beginning before the first assumed-valid block)
    4211                 :            :                 // might not get added to the background chainstate, but this is ok,
    4212                 :            :                 // because they will still be attached to the active chainstate if they
    4213                 :            :                 // actually contain more work.
    4214                 :            :                 //
    4215                 :            :                 // Instead of this height-based approach, an earlier attempt was made at
    4216                 :            :                 // detecting "holistically" whether the block index under consideration
    4217                 :            :                 // relied on an assumed-valid ancestor, but this proved to be too slow to
    4218                 :            :                 // be practical.

    4293                 :            :

    4305                 :          0 :                     continue;

    4755                 :            :     }
    4756                 :            : 
    4757                 :          8 :     int64_t current_coinsdb_cache_size{0};
    4758                 :          8 :     int64_t current_coinstip_cache_size{0};
    4759                 :            : 
    4760                 :            :     // Cache percentages to allocate to each chainstate.
    4761                 :            :     //
    4762                 :            :     // These particular percentages don't matter so much since they will only be
    4763                 :            :     // relevant during snapshot activation; caches are rebalanced at the conclusion of
    4764                 :            :     // this function. We want to give (essentially) all available cache capacity to the
    4765                 :            :     // snapshot to aid the bulk load later in this function.
    4766                 :            :     static constexpr double IBD_CACHE_PERC = 0.01;
    4767                 :            :     static constexpr double SNAPSHOT_CACHE_PERC = 0.99;
    4768                 :            : 
    4769                 :            :     {
    4770                 :         16 :         LOCK(::cs_main);
    4771                 :            :         // Resize the coins caches to ensure we're not exceeding memory limits.
    4772                 :            :         //
    4773                 :            :         // Allocate the majority of the cache to the incoming snapshot chainstate, since
    4774                 :            :         // (optimistically) getting to its tip will be the top priority. We'll need to call
    4775                 :            :         // `MaybeRebalanceCaches()` once we're done with this function to ensure
    4776                 :            :         // the right allocation (including the possibility that no snapshot was activated
    4777                 :            :         // and that we should restore the active chainstate caches to their original size).
    4778                 :            :         //
